  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/nucl-ex/0101007v1</id>
    <title>Time-of-Flight Spectroscopy of Muonic Hydrogen Atoms and Molecules</title>
    <updated>2001-01-22T15:48:13Z</updated>
    <link href="https://arxiv.org/abs/nucl-ex/0101007v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/nucl-ex/0101007v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf" title="pdf"/>
    <summary>  Studies of muonic hydrogen atoms and molecules have been performed traditionally in bulk targets of gas, liquid or solid. At TRIUMF, Canada's meson facility, we have developed a new type of target system using multilayer thin films of solid hydrogen, which provides a beam of muonic hydrogen atoms in vacuum. Using the time-of-flight of the muonic atoms, the energy-dependent information of muonic reactions are obtained in direct manner. We discuss some unique measurements enabled by the new technique, with emphasis on processes relevant to muon catalyzed fusion.</summary>
    <category term="nucl-ex" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="hep-ex" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <category term="physics.atom-ph" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <published>2001-01-22T15:48:13Z</published>
    <arxiv:comment>Contribution to Hydrogen Atom II --- Precise Physics with Simple Atomic Systems (Springer, Berlin)</arxiv:comment>
    <arxiv:primary_category term="nucl-ex"/>

  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0890v1</id>
    <title>Metal hydride material requirements for automotive hydrogen storage systems</title>
    <updated>2013-07-03T01:00:46Z</updated>
    <link href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.0890v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.0890v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf" title="pdf"/>
    <summary>The United States Department of Energy (DOE) has published a progression of technical targets to be satisfied by on-board rechargeable hydrogen storage systems in light-duty vehicles. By combining simplified storage system and vehicle models with interpolated data from metal hydride databases, we obtain material-level requirements for metal hydrides that can be assembled into systems that satisfy the DOE targets for 2017. We assume minimal balance-of-plant components for systems with and without a hydrogen combustion loop for supplemental heating. Tank weight and volume are driven by the stringent requirements for refueling time. The resulting requirements suggest that, at least for this specific application, no current on-board rechargeable metal hydride satisfies these requirements.</summary>
    <category term="cond-mat.mtrl-sci" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <published>2013-07-03T01:00:46Z</published>
    <arxiv:comment>11 pages, 12 figures, 2 tables, to appear in the International Journal of Hydrogen Energy</arxiv:comment>
    <arxiv:primary_category term="cond-mat.mtrl-sci"/>
    <arxiv:journal_ref>Int. J. Hydrogen Energy vol. 38, pp. 9755-9765 (2013)</arxiv:journal_ref>
    <author>

  </entry>
  <entry>
    <id>http://arxiv.org/abs/physics/0009069v1</id>
    <title>Lamb Shift in Light Hydrogen-Like Atoms</title>
    <updated>2000-09-23T11:55:55Z</updated>
    <link href="https://arxiv.org/abs/physics/0009069v1" rel="alternate" type="text/html"/>
    <link href="https://arxiv.org/pdf/physics/0009069v1" rel="related" type="application/pdf" title="pdf"/>
    <summary>  Calculation of higher-order two-loop corrections is now a limiting factor in development of the bound state QED theory of the Lamb shift in the hydrogen atom and in precision determination of the Rydberg constant. Progress in the study of light hydrogen-like ions of helium and nitrogen can be helpful to investigate these uncalculated terms experimentally. To do that it is necessary to develop a theory of such ions. We present here a theoretical calculation for low energy levels of helium and nitrogen ions.</summary>
    <category term="physics.atom-ph" scheme="http://arxiv.org/schemas/atom"/>
    <published>2000-09-23T11:55:55Z</published>
    <arxiv:comment>15 pages, 6 figures, presented at Hydrogen atom, 2 meeting (2000)</arxiv:comment>
    <arxiv:primary_category term="physics.atom-ph"/>
    <arxiv:journal_ref>In Hydrogen atom: Precision physics of simple atomic systems. Ed. by S. G. Karshenboim et al., (Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg, 2001) pp. 637-650</arxiv:journal_ref>
    <author>
      <name>Vladimir G. Ivanov</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation>Pulkovo Observatory, St. Petersburg, Russia</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
    <author>
      <name>Savely G. Karshenboim</name>
      <arxiv:affiliation>D. I. Mendeleev Institute for Metrology, St. Petersburg, Russia</arxiv:affiliation>
      <arxiv:affiliation>Max-Planck-Institut fur Quantenoptik, Garching, Germany</arxiv:affiliation>
    </author>
  </entry>

  • Valence oscillation and dynamic active sites in monolayer NiCo hydroxides for water oxidation

    Layered double hydroxides of transition metals are known to be highly active for water oxidation, but the nature of their active sites and reaction mechanism are still elusive. Now, a monolayer NiCo hydroxide catalyst, in situ prepared on the working electrode, is reported to exhibit valence oscillation and dynamic generation of active sites during water oxidation.

  • Indications of chemical bond contrast in AFM images of a hydrogen-terminated silicon surface

    Whether and under what circumstances chemical bonds could be imaged via force microscopy is a controversial topic. Here authors develop a particular combination of model surface, imaging procedures and simulation approach and discuss possible indications of chemical contrast in imaging data they obtain.

    • Robert A. Wolkow
    ResearchOpen Access13 Feb 2017

  • Polarimetric detection of non-radial oscillation modes in the β Cephei star β Crucis

  • Sub-10-fs control of dissociation pathways in the hydrogen molecular ion with a few-pulse attosecond pulse train

    Towards the end of their lives, stars like the Sun expand greatly to become red giant stars that oscillate. Here, the presence of such oscillations in more than 300 giant stars is reported, with mode lifetimes of some of the giants in the order of a month.

  • Coherent terahertz radiation with 2.8-octave tunability through chip-scale photomixed microresonator optical parametric oscillation

    High-spectral-purity frequency-agile room-temperature THz sources are foundational elements for imaging, sensing, metrology, and communications. Here a parametric oscillator-photomixer chip with coherent 2.8-octave tunable THz radiation is achieved.

    • Wenting Wang

  • Electron-beam energy reconstruction for neutrino oscillation measurements

  • Gravity modes as a way to distinguish between hydrogen- and helium-burning red giant stars

    Red giants are evolved stars that have exhausted the supply of hydrogen in their cores and instead burn hydrogen in a surrounding shell. Once a red giant is sufficiently evolved, the helium in the core also undergoes fusion. However, it is difficult to distinguish between the two groups. Asteroseismology offers a way forward. This study reports observations of gravity-mode period spacings in red giants using high precision photometry obtained by the Kepler spacecraft. It is found that the stars fall into two clear groups, making it possible to distinguish unambiguously between hydrogen-shell-burning stars and those that are also burning helium.

  • Electroreduction-driven distorted nanotwins activate pure Cu for efficient hydrogen evolution

    Low-cost Cu catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) can transform industrial water electrolysis, but pure Cu typically exhibits a negligible HER.     Volume: 7, P: 1-8

  • On the origin of accretion flow photon index–quasi-periodic oscillation frequency (Γ–vQPO) relation

    • Ambrose C. Eze
    • Romanus N. C. Eze
    • Fidelis Okey Madu
    ResearchOpen Access04 Apr 2025
    Scientific Reports
    Volume: 15, P: 1-11

  • A carbon-nanotube-based electron source with a 0.3-eV energy spread and an unconventional time delay

    Metal-tip-based electron sources are constrained by a trade-off between energy spread and pulse width. Here the authors report a carbon-nanotube-based electron source with a 0.3-eV energy spread and an electron pulse width of about 13 fs.

    • Ke Chen
    • Chao Yu
    • Qing Dai
    Research02 Jul 2025
    Nature Materials
    Volume: 24, P: 1773-1777

  • Pressure-induced bonding and compound formation in xenon–hydrogen solids

    Both hydrogen and xenon form unusual phases at very high pressures. Researchers have now observed that an unexpectedly stable compound forms when a hydrogen-rich mixture of the two gases is subjected to pressures in the gigapascal range. Xenon dimers and other unusual bonding states are revealed in this compound, which is stable to megabar pressures.

    • Maddury Somayazulu
    • Przemyslaw Dera
    • Russell J. Hemley
    Research22 Nov 2009
    Nature Chemistry
    Volume: 2, P: 50-53
